# What makes a computer a computer? #

Man wanted to create something that could manipulate information. 

In order for the pioneers to create a "thinking machine" they needed it to be able to: 

>1. Take input
>2. store information
>3. Process the information
>4. Output

These four things are common to ALL computers and that is what makes a computer a computer. 

The earlier computers used to be made of wood and gears. As technology advanced they began to use electrical components. They aren't what we know today...they started out as large and heavy machines that would take up a room to simply execute a calculation. 

#### Input ####

This is where you can tell a computer what to do with the information given to it. How to work with the headphones or keyboard or mouse etc. These inputs are stored as information in memory. A computers processor takes the information and changes it using algorithims (a series of commands) and stored again until it is ready to be output. 

#### Output ####

This depends on what it was designed to do. A display could show texts and movies, or an output could control a robot and when connected via internet the output from one computer can be the input for another. 

## Binary and Data ##

Bit: smallest piece of information...ie: with one wire you can give an "off/on" state, something that can only give you two options.

The binary number system: there are only two digits: 0 and 1. 

No one deals directly with binary numbers but they are the skeleton of how all computers input, store, process and output information. 

![image](data:image/png;base64,)

We are all used to the decimal system. Where each number has a place; ones, tens, hundreds etc. Each place is multiplied by 10. With the binary number system each places is multiplied by 2...ones, twos, fours, eights etc. This allows for any number to be represented. 

>For example with 8 wires you can store from 0-255. With 32 wires you can store from 0 to over 4 billion. 

By assigning numbers to *letters*, you can put any word together using a sequence of numbers. *Photos* are represented in their smallest state, pixels. Each pixel has an assigned number, each picture or video has billions of pixels...imagine the number of data needed. *Sounds* are a series of waverforms...any point on a waveform can be represented by a number. This way, any sound can be broken down into a series of numbers.

## Circuits and Logic ##

A computer uses tiny electornic components that come together to form circuits to help them take the inputs and outputs and give us what we see. 

A simple circuit takes an electrical signal and flips it. So if you give it a one...it'll give you a zero. 

#### LOGIC GATES: ####  
--------------
#### | AND | NAND | NOT | NOR | OR | XOR | ####
--------------

Small circuits that perform simple logical calculations. By connecting the *logic gates* together you can make more complex circuits that perform more complex calculations. 

## CPU, Memory, Input & Output ##

![flow](https://benjenkins.weebly.com/uploads/9/1/5/7/9157981/4446086.jpg?776)

-Input devices: take input from the outside world and converts it to binary information. 
-Memory: stores the information. 
-CPU: Central processing unit where all the calculations are done.
-Output devices: take information and convert it into physical output.
